description:
Bartonella pachyuromydis is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Bartonella. This genus comprises a group of fastidious, intracellular, Gram-negative bacteria that are primarily associated with various mammalian hosts, including humans.

Bartonella pachyuromydis was first isolated from the blood of the greater dwarf lemur (Cheirogaleus major), a primate species endemic to the island of Madagascar. The bacterium was named based on its host, the greater dwarf lemur, with the specific epithet "pachyuromydis" referring to the scientific name of the host species.

As a member of the genus Bartonella, B. pachyuromydis is capable of infecting and colonizing the endothelial cells of the host's blood vessels. This ability allows the bacteria to evade the host's immune system and establish a persistent infection. The specific mechanisms and pathogenicity of B. pachyuromydis in its primate host are not yet fully understood and require further investigation.

Research on this species is limited, and its potential impact on the health and ecology of the greater dwarf lemur population in Madagascar is an area that warrants further study. Understanding the interactions between B. pachyuromydis and its primate host can provide valuable insights into the evolutionary dynamics and disease dynamics within this unique ecosystem.
